President Alters SAC Discipline Code
By MICHAEL HILL
President Gordon has released to the press his
final policy statement on University discipline, a
report that contains several differences from
the proposed issued by the Committee on Student Affairs.
In a ten-page explanatory letter attached to
the policy statement, Gordon stated that he
will give "serious consideration" to any petition
for a specific amendment which is signed by
more than 25% of the faculty or student body
of any section of the University.
Gordon has, in his report, altered the composition of the Review Board as proposed by the
Committee on Student Affairs. The latest proposal has the board composed of three students
three faculty . members and one administrator.
The Committee's report had requested two
graduate students, two undergraduate students,
two faculty members and one administrator.
Gordon stated that this change, which maidtains the ratio on the review board proposed by
an ad hoc discipline Committee last summer,
would prevent any segment of the community .
from having a majority of members. He believed
a majority of any interest group would be
undesirable.
In addition, Gordon retained expulsion as a
punishment. The SAC had eliminated that and,
instead, suggested the possibility of "indefinite
suspension," with a yearly appeal. Gordon felt
that this would set up two separate admissions
procedures. He also suggested that the yearly appeal might turn into a "sideshow."
Gordon also added the phrase "conduct that

impairs the effective functioning of the University..." to the definition of behavior subject to
sanctions. He did not feel that sanctioning only
,behavior that infringed upon the rights of other
people or groups would be sufficient.
Further changes were made in the selection
procedures and rules for open meetings of the
Review Board. Gordon gave the Board the power
to close its meetings, as he claimed open meetings "might invite disruptive tactics."
The Student Affairs Committee was not informed by Gordon of his new proposal. This was
called by SAC Chairman John White of Art History as "rude." Richard Conviser, a member of
SAC, stated that the president had "violated"
the trust of the committee. He claimed that
he would approve the SAC's proposal and, because of this, "we went to the right of our first
draft." He called Gordon's new statemenf "A
backwards way of doing things."
Dr. Steve Mann of the Education department,
a member of the Student Affairs Committee,
stated, "He is wrong and we are right," when
asked his opinion of Gordon's report. SAC will
officially respond to the new proposal next
week.
Bob Cotter, president of the Graduate Student
Organization and also a member of the Committee, commented that they were "sucked into this
on good faith of having some sort of compromise," and since Gordon had violated "that sort
of agreement, we should throw out the whole
thing." He accused Gordon of being "paranoid."
Gordon sent copies .of his revision of the ad
hoc Committee's report to the administrative
heads of the University's four divisions, asking

that they discuss it with whomever they deemed
necessary. All divisions except Homewood sent
back the report unchanged last fall.
In the Arts and Sciences division, Dean Kimball referred it to SAC, who considered the report last semester and sent back their recommendations at the beginning of January. It was
from these reports and conversations with faculty members that Gordon reached his final
decision. Gordon stated that a covering letter
on the SAC report from Dean Kimball expressed
concern at the number of changes SAC had
made. Gordon said that he also took these comments into consideration.

Gordon Advocates State Agency
For Hospital and College Growth
Testifying before the State Senate Finance Committee on Tuesday, Lincoln Gordon advocated
formation of a statewide borrowing authority to aid Maryland's
private. universities and hospitals
in financing construction.
Identical bills providing for the
formation of a Maryland Health
and Higher Educational Facilities
Authority are now in committees
of the Senate and General Assembly. The bills were pre-filed early in
November by Governor Mandel's
office. Besides gubernatorial support, there appears to be a solid
majority in both houses which
favors the bill.
The idea was first proposed to
Governor Mandel by Lincoln Gordon and the bills were originally
drafted by the Hopkins legal staff.
The model for the borrowing
agency was derived from similar
agencies now in operation in nine
states.
The Authority, if constituted in
its present form, would substantially reduce the borrowing costs of
private institutions throughout the
•-

state. It would be empowered to
issue revenue bonds against the
collective credit of all of the
state's private medical and educational institutions, thus substantially reducing the interest required
for financing.
Revenue bonds issued against
the credit of the proposed agency
might carry an interest rate of 6.5%
to 7.5%. Private health and educational institutions which can now
arrange financing through commercial loans are paying up to 11.5%.
In addition to the added security
which stems from the collective
credit of all private institutions,
bonds issued by the agency will be
exempt from federal and state
taxation. They are thus more attractive to bond-holders, who need
not pay taxes on income from the
bonds.
The state will not have to donate
any revenues to the new Agency,
nor will the state's credit be on the
line when the Agency issues bonds.
The authority will be set up with
revenues allocated by the private
institutions themselves.

There appears to be little danger
that the bill will not be passed in
this session of the legislature. According to Frank DeFilippo, Governor Mandel's Press Secretary, no
opposition to the measure has
shown itself in either house. John
C. Eldridge, Legislative Aide to
Mandel, said, "How can anyone
oppose it? There's not a penny of
state money involved—not even to
set the agency up."
Hopkins will doubtless be the
school to benefit most from the
new agency. In his testimony,
Gordon assured the members of
the Finance Committee that Hopkins' planning $ 1 2 million per
year. The total from all of Maryland's other institutions of higher
learning will probably be considerably less than that figure.
At present Hopkins is only planning one construction project
which might be financed through
the new agency. The planned parking garage, to be constructed at a
cost of $3.5 million, might be financed in part or wholly by bonds
issued by the agency.

"For the next three years," Gordon stated,"we anticipate no more
than $5 million per year." He went
on to say that he could not estimate the borrowing needs of the
"hospital side." However, the total
hospital construction expenditures
in the entire state has averaged
only about $12 million per year
for the last two decades.
Apart from new construction
projects, the authority would be
able to lend money to colleges
and hospitals for the retirement ofy
outstanding loans and mortgages
carrying higher interest rates.
As it is presently construed, the
bill would apply equally to private
and state schools. There was a
proposal in committee, this week,
to eliminate state schools from
the authority. State schools can
borrow money on the credit of the
state; consequently at lower rates
of interest than would be made
possible by the new agency.
In testimony supporting passage
of the bills, Gordon cited the successful establishment of similar
agencies in other states.

Dorms Draw DSRC Complaint
By RALPH MOLLER

A common scene for the 585 students who inhabit Hopkins' dorms.

Growing dissatisfaction among dorm
residents about their living conditions
has aroused the normally impotent
Dormitory Student Representative
Council.
This dissatisfaction was underscored
by a resolution passed in the Dormitory
Student
Representative
Council on
Thursday, January 29. It called for the

to the Baltimore City Department
of
Housing.
In this letter, the DSRC said that it
at

Hopkins, "particularly the old dormitory, do not meet the Building Code and
that the University should be made aware

Building Inspection."
The sponsor of this resolution Martin

Vogel, Vice-President of the DSRC,said

ventilation and the lack of enough living
space per person prompted him to take

Recruitment Triples Black Applications
Applications by black high school students for admission
to next year's freshman class have been extremely high
due to an intensive recruiting campaign, accordin
g to
Assistant Director of Admissions Ronald Owens.
Over two hundred applications came into the admissions
office by the February 1 deadline. The number is better
than three times the quanity of applications received at
this time last year.
Included in this number are nine applicationsfrom local
black women interested in comingto Hopkins. Also, three
black girls have filed applications to enter as transfer students next year.
Owens claimed that a major reason for the sharp increase in applications was that the admissions office
"mounted a massive campaign" to indicate that Hopkins
is interested in black students.
He estimated that "two
thousand students have been contacted to show students
that we are interested."
Many blacks said that they had been interested
in Hopkins, but they had thought that Hopkins was
not interested
In them, Owens claimed.
Once the interest was reciprocated, a strong response was received.
Owens attributed much of the success of the campaign
to black students presentl
y enrolled at Hopkins who devoted much of their intersession to talking
with potential
applicants. Several blacks travelled around the country
to speak about Hopkins
with high school seniors. The
effort was particularly intensive in Texas,
Florida and
throughout New England.
There has been a nationwide distribution of
applicants,
but a majority have come from the
East Coast. Maryland,
New York, New Jersey, and Pennsylv
ania are the largest
contributors of candidates with applications coming
from
California and some Western states.
Owens attributes the concentration to the fact
that although Hopkins has a worldwide reputatio
n it is better
known in the East than other parts of
the country. He
indicated that the distribution of black applicants is not
Significantly different from that of whites.

"This is probably the best way of recruiting for
your school," said Owens, because if you can get current
students to push the school, then others will be more
interested. He claimed that this could be the "key to
the whole thing."
A major concern of the campaign was to generate
interest among black high school students in going to
college, then if they show interest they are asked to
consider Hopkins. Owens is concerned with getting
more blacks to go on to college as well as to get more
onto the Homewood campus.
Owens explained that when he goes to a high school
to recruit students, much of what he wants to do is to
show that someone is interested in them. He then
offers Hopkins as a possible choice in an effort to
"offer a broader choice of colleges."
.The admissions officer claimed that many of the students who have applied this year show great potential
as successful college students. "A great number are
articulate and bright, but not all have been so good.
That's the name of the game for admissions," said
Owens.
Applicants have indicated interest in varied fields,
ranging from physics and chemistry to history or
psychology. Owens stated that he is pleased with the
blend in interest shown by those who want to come
to Hopkins.
The admissions office now has to consider which of
the students should be admitted to Hopkins. The next
major task is to get those who are accepted to come
to Hopkins next year. Owens said that many of the
applicants would probably get accepted by most of the
schools they apply to, and that Hopkins would have to
attract them to Homewood.
William Brinkley, Director of Admissions, stated
that he is very pleased with the work that Owens and
others have done. He also expressed trust that more
blacks will come to Hopkins as a result of the program that has been conducted this year.

Whites Asked to Drop Crowded Black Lit Class

. confusion, concurre
nce

instructor in Dr. Richard Macksey's
"‘Black Literature in America" course
suggested that white students drop the
course.
Moorer made no attempt to evict the
White students from the lecture, but
stated that he hoped to be "so drastically boring that you (whites) will take

the incentive and leave."
Three whites actually left the lecture.
Macksey said he doubts that many more
whites will drop the course. "There are
too many masochists around for that,"
he added.
Moorer said that he "didn't have time"
to teach white students about black literature. That kind of course, he said,

but Moorer did admit two whites who
approached him personally.
Moorer refused to comment on his
statements, Wednesday night. He said,
"I see no reason why a class should have
to explain to a newspaper what is going
on."

By STEVE BUCKINGHAM
Last Wednesday Dr. Abel Wolman
furnished a group of interested listeners a large amount of information and
opinion relating to a subject which has
recently become a matter of much public
concern; water pollution.
Dr. Wolman, one of the University's
Professors Emeritus, gave his views
on the management of the Chesapeake
Bay to a crowded room of over 40
people in the top of Ames Hall. Among
those present were students and many
faculty members including Dr. M. G.
Wolman of the Georgraphy and Environmental
Engineering Department, the
speaker's son.
After noting the grave problems confronting the Bay at the present and the
events leading to their existence, he
turned to the attempts to solve them.
There are, he said, thirty-nine administrative agencies concerned with management of the Bay. And from these
agencies have come a few similar recommendations for action.
All of these groups propose additional study. This seems to be, according
to Wolman, "the number-one solution,
not always emanating from academic,
but from commissioners created to do
this, to do that. As someone has said
recently on the Federal level, 'If you
don't want anything done, appoint a
commission to inquire it." Dr. Wolman criticized this as an answer to
the problem because it provided for
no action, just study.
The second possible action is the
declaration of a moratorium on all
decisions and actions. This, of course,
is a very negative approach. Any public
official concerned with management of

the Chesapeake could say that he does
not know enough and therefore should
not act at all.
The last recommendation that is frequently made is concerned with reorganization. "Whenever anyone's confronted with a dilemma, again looking

Wolman.
"A militant public opinion is obviously mandatory. However, it generates in

"do not have to depend on the emergence of additional scientific and technological information. They are worth

results may prove to be."

Governor's office would take a responsible role in managing the Chesapeake.

all the existing agencies) in the state

executive level. There is that opportunity, and let us presume that it (probably) will be made."

Finally, after months of delay, an ad
hoc faculty Committee on Governance
has been formed to discover whether
"widespread dissatisfaction" with the

Faculty General Assembly to set up

Committee was appointed last month by

the power to appoint the Committee in

he had difficulty in getting faculty members to serve.

Beer indicated that he had looked for a
wide distribution in disciplines. The
members of the Committee are Dr.
Woodford Howard of Political Science,
Dr. John Baldwin of History, Dr. Maurice Bessman of Biology, Dr. Jan Minkowski of Electrical Engineering and
Professor Jerome Perlstein of Chemistry.
Beer said that he had avoided
faculty members with extreme views
on the governance issue.
The Committee met with Beer a couple

of weeks ago to clarify their task. They
chose Howard as chairman because, as
Bessman put it, Howard i s in Political
Science and i s perhaps better qualified
to handle the post. Howard was not
present at the meeting. The Committee
had its first formal meeting at the
Faculty Club yesterday.

The Academic Council has charged
the Committee with determining "the

magnitude of. dissatisfaction (with the
governance of the Division of Arts and
Sciences) and recommend procedures."
A proposal that might be considered by
the Committee if it finds enough "dissatisfaction" was offered by Dr. Francis Rourke, Chairman of the Political
Science Department. Rourke suggested
that if a second Committee was recommended by the present one, it should be
paid to work over the summer. Such a
step, said Rourke, would "keep the
momentun of such a study going."
There has been no recent student
action on the governance issue. The
Student Council has not had a quorum
at its rec9nt meetings, but some members stated that they will discuss governance at their Monday meeting.

of the Committee's, and would create
misunderstanding before the Committee
had even met. Howard said that he would
discuss Committee business as soon as
it started its planning.

thinking" about the problems of governance before he was appointed to
serve on the Committee. He accepted
the post, he said, as part of his "university obligation." Bessman believed

about the subject through his committee work. Other Committee members
could not be reached for comment.

he was "puzzled on how to approach
it," although he opposed putting the
issue into faculty hands. "I am against
the faculty doing this (governance) on

It should surprise no one that Lincoln Gordon has rewritten the draft of
the discipline code submitted to him by the Committee on Student

of expulsion for an offending student. The second involved the composition of the review board. At the time, Dr. Gordon's plan was to man the
review board with two students, two faculty members and one administrator.
The Committee on Student Affairs studied the proposal and recomended that both of these facets of the code be altered. Expulsion, the report
of the committee contends, does not allow for the possibility of rehabilitation and concentrates on punishing, rather than reforming the student
involved. The committee recommended that long-term suspension be the
severest penalty admissible.
Dr. Gordon promptly replaced expulsion on the list of admissible
penalties. It apparently does not concern Dr. Gordon that a student who
is expelled carries that stigma throughout his life. Expulsion is irrevocable.
The President's rationale for this move centers on the fact that the student
can always reapply through normal admissions procedures. It would be
unfeasible, his report reads, to have two manners of admitting students.
How many students does Dr. Gordon plan to kick out? Would their numbers place such a strain on Hopkins' bureaucratic workings?
The Committee on Student Affairs also changed the composition of the
review board for the better. Instead of two students, two faculty members and an administrator, the Committee's review board was comprised of

administrator. It seems only reasonable that students should be in the
majority of a board which is called upon to judge only students. The

Since its opening in March 1969, the
Johns Hopkins Drug Abuse Center has
found itself confronted by the combined

Headed by Dr. Leon Furmser,\ the

One of the major reaons why the 200

Though most of the addicts are from

The Only One
The Drug Abuse Center is the only

The older Project Adapt and Man Alive
organizations were established as maintenance clinics where heroin addicts
could come and receive free treatment
and narcotics substitutes. The Drug
Abuse Center, however, is attempting
not only maintenance of the drug addict
but also the long-range posibility of complete detoxification.
Because the center supports only one
full-time and four part-time physicians,
the waiting-list for care at the center
is long, and, due to this need for selectivity
of patients, uncooperative or
troublesome addicts must seek other
alternatives. Of prime importance to the
functioning of this program is the sin-

cerity and motivation of the addict himself. It is up to the addict to return
promptly for daily medication and weekly
counseling sessions.
Many addicts are, however, pressured
either by family, probation officers or the
courts to attend the center, according to
its staff members. Unfortunately, such
pressures hardly insure that the addict
has any desire to quit and many such

10,000 Baltimore Addicts

fullest. In treating heroin and cocaine

narcotic substance called methadone.

instead of heroin. Methadone has none
of the withdraw al and vomiting symptoms

Heroin also has a cummulative affect,

monitor the addict's progress and, hopefully, to motivate him to quit at a later

Governance Issue Goes into Committee at Last
Finally, after months of delay, an ad
hoc faculty Committee on Governance
has been formed to discover whether
"widespread dissatisfaction" with the
governance exists at Homewood.
The Academic Council directed the
Faculty General Assembly to set up
such a committee last October 15. The
Committee was appointed last month by
Dr. Michael Beer, Vice-Chairman of the
General Assembly. Beer, who was given
the power to appoint the Committee in
a faculty ballot in December, said that
he had difficulty in getting faculty members to serve.
In appointing the faculty members,
Beer indicated that he had looked for a
wide distribution in disciplines. The
members of the Committee are Dr.
Woodford Howard of Political Science,
Dr. John Baldwin of History, Dr. Maurice Bessman of Biology, Dr. Jan Minkowski of Electrical Engineering and
Professor Jerome Perlstein of Chemistry.
Beer said that he had avoided
faculty members with extreme views
on the governance issue.
The Committee met with Beer a couple

of weeks ago to clarify their task. They
chose Howard as chairman because, as
Bessman put it, Howard i s in Political
Science and i s perhaps better qualified
to handle the post. Howard was not
present at the meeting. The Committee
had its first formal meeting at the
Faculty Club yesterday.

The Academic Council has charged
the Committee with determining "the

magnitude of. dissatisfaction (with the
governance of the Division of Arts and
Sciences) and recommend procedures."
A proposal that might be considered by
the Committee if it finds enough "dissatisfaction" was offered by Dr. Francis Rourke, Chairman of the Political
Science Department. Rourke suggested
that if a second Committee was recommended by the present one, it should be
paid to work over the summer. Such a
step, said Rourke, would "keep the
momentun of such a study going."
There has been no recent student
action on the governance issue. The
Student Council has not had a quorum
at its rec9nt meetings, but some members stated that they will discuss governance at their Monday meeting.

"Keep Momentum"
Howard declined to comment on Committee plans. He felt that his own opinions might be misinterpreted as those
of the Committee's, and would create
misunderstanding before the Committee
had even met. Howard said that he would
discuss Committee business as soon as
it started its planning.
Bessman said that he "hadn't been
thinking" about the problems of governance before he was appointed to
serve on the Committee. He accepted
the post, he said, as part of his "university obligation." Bessman believed
that he would be able to learn more
about the subject through his committee work. Other Committee members
could not be reached for comment.

Bob Cotter, President of the Graduate Students Organization said, "We
haven't done anything about the governance issue." Cotter also said that
he was "puzzled on how to approach
it," although he opposed putting the
issue into faculty hands. "I am against
the faculty doing this (governance) on
its own," he stated.

Dr. Woodford Howard of Political Science
was chosen to head the ad hoc Governance
Committee due to his scholarly knowledge
of politics.

Surprise! Surprise!
It should surprise no one that Lincoln Gordon has rewritten the draft of
the discipline code submitted to him by the Committee on Student
Affairs, and in substance completely rejected the recommendations of the
Committee. Dr. Gordon is a firm proponent of committees, student "input" and other administrative devices. However, when the duly constituted committee on Student Affairs released the findings of four months'
work, and issued a reasonable version of Dr. Gordon's discipline code, he
saw nothing amiss in returning the code to its original intolerable form.
The fact that the committee was not contacted after it had released its
report is not surprising either, considering Dr. Gordon's obvious disregard
for its recommendations.
In September, Dr. Gordon proposed a discipline code which was objectionable on two counts primarily. The first point involved the possibility
of expulsion for an offending student. The second involved the composition of the review board. At the time, Dr. Gordon's plan was to man the
review board with two students, two faculty members and one administrator.
The Committee on Student Affairs studied the proposal and recomended that both of these facets of the code be altered. Expulsion, the report
of the committee contends, does not allow for the possibility of rehabilitation and concentrates on punishing, rather than reforming the student
involved. The committee recommended that long-term suspension be the
severest penalty admissible.
Dr. Gordon promptly replaced expulsion on the list of admissible
penalties. It apparently does not concern Dr. Gordon that a student who
is expelled carries that stigma throughout his life. Expulsion is irrevocable.
The President's rationale for this move centers on the fact that the student
can always reapply through normal admissions procedures. It would be
unfeasible, his report reads, to have two manners of admitting students.
How many students does Dr. Gordon plan to kick out? Would their numbers place such a strain on Hopkins' bureaucratic workings?
The Committee on Student Affairs also changed the composition of the
review board for the better. Instead of two students, two faculty members and an administrator, the Committee's review board was comprised of
two undergraduates, two graduate students, two faculty members and an
administrator. It seems only reasonable that students should be in the
majority of a board which is called upon to judge only students. The
Committee added the administrator to'the board only when Dr. Gordon
insisted.
But a lone administrator here and there is not enough for Dr. Gordon
He completely reversed the Committee's recommendations and swung the
balance on the board away from the students again. Dr. Gordon insists
that faculty and students have an equal number of representatives with an
administrator holding the deciding vote.
In justifying ignoring this part of the Committee's recommendations, Dr.
Gordon states that since Hopkins is a community (uh huh), all segments
of the University should get equal representation. Should all segments of
the community be subject to this discipline code? Should not any consideration be given to the fact that the students comprise eighty-five percent of this community? Does equal representation involve giving an administrator the swing-vote on the review board for students?
If Hopkins is truly a community, Dr. Gordon would agree that every
segment of that community should be accorded the respect which accrues
to an equal partner. Unfortunately, he is not long on respect when a
committee tries to tamper with one of his master-plans. Such tamperings
tend to get ignored.
And if anyone is upset, all he need do is sign a petition protesting any
part of the President's statement. Dr. Gordon does not expect to see such
a petition. If students want to see a just discipline policy, however, they
will have to put together just such a petition, at least as a first step. We
suggest that if the Student Council can raise a quorum, the organization
for a petition might be a welcome reminder of the Council's existence
The Graduate Student Organization and concerned faculty members
should make a similar effort. We must warn, however, that getting Dr.
Gordon to rethink a section of his discipline code will probably net yield a
reasonable policy. It is a first step only.

Since its opening in March 1969, the
Johns Hopkins Drug Abuse Center has
found itself confronted by the combined

Headed by Dr. Leon Furmser,\ the

One of the major reaons why the 200

Though most of the addicts are from

The Only One
The Drug Abuse Center is the only

The older Project Adapt and Man Alive
organizations were established as maintenance clinics where heroin addicts
could come and receive free treatment
and narcotics substitutes. The Drug
Abuse Center, however, is attempting
not only maintenance of the drug addict
but also the long-range posibility of complete detoxification.
Because the center supports only one
full-time and four part-time physicians,
the waiting-list for care at the center
is long, and, due to this need for selectivity
of patients, uncooperative or
troublesome addicts must seek other
alternatives. Of prime importance to the
functioning of this program is the sin-

cerity and motivation of the addict himself. It is up to the addict to return
promptly for daily medication and weekly
counseling sessions.
Many addicts are, however, pressured
either by family, probation officers or the
courts to attend the center, according to
its staff members. Unfortunately, such
pressures hardly insure that the addict

10,000 Baltimore Addicts

instead of heroin. Methadone has none
of the withdraw al and vomiting symptoms

monitor the addict's progress and, hopefully, to motivate him to quit at a later
